subject: linear_algebra
title: Interpretations of Matrix Multiplication
contentHtml: In this worked example, we'll explore different interpretations of matrix multiplication.

problem.statementHtml: Given two matrices A and B, compute the matrix product AB.
hints: Think about linear combinations of columns
problem.solutionHtml:
We can interpret matrix multiplication in various ways:

  • As a linear combination of columns: \[\mathbf{AB} = \sum_{j=1}^m \mathbf{a}_j b_j^T\]
  • As a dot product between rows and columns: \[\mathbf{AB} = \sum_{i=1}^n \mathbf{a}_i (\mathbf{B}\mathbf{b}_i)^T\]

steps.description: Write the matrices as linear combinations of columns
steps.explanation: This helps us see the linear combination of columns

steps.description: Compute the dot products between rows and columns
steps.explanation: This shows the dot product between rows and columns
This gives us the final matrix product

intuition: Matrix multiplication can be seen as a combination of linear combinations and dot products, allowing us to compute complex relationships between vectors.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Interpreting Matrix Multiplication
contentHtml: In this worked example, we'll explore how to interpret the result of matrix multiplication.
problemHtml: Given two matrices A and B, compute the product C = AB.
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Write down the formula for matrix multiplication.", "mathHtml": "\[C_{ij} = \sum_k A_{ik}B_{kj}\]", "explanation": "We're using the definition of matrix multiplication to compute each entry in C."}, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Expand the formula for one entry in C.", "mathHtml": "\[C_{11} = \sum_k A_{1k}B_{k1}\]", "explanation": "This helps us see that matrix multiplication is a linear combination of columns from B."}, {"stepNumber": 3, "description": "Notice the dot product between rows in A and columns in B.", "mathHtml": "\[C_{11} = \sum_k (A_{1k} \cdot B_{k1})\]", "explanation": "This shows that matrix multiplication can be viewed as a collection of dot products."}, {"stepNumber": 4, "description": "Consider the outer product of two vectors.", "mathHtml": "\[C = uv^T\]", "explanation": "We can think of matrix multiplication as a way to compute the outer product of each row in A with each column in B."}, {"stepNumber": 5, "description": "Block multiply matrices.", "mathHtml": "\[\begin{bmatrix}A_1 & A_2\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}B_1 \\ B_2\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}A_1B_1 + A_2B_2\end{bmatrix}\]", "explanation": "This illustrates how matrix multiplication can be used to combine matrices in a block-wise manner."} ],
finalAnswer: The product C = AB is computed by iterating over the entries of the matrices and applying the formula." },
intuition: Matrix multiplication is a way to combine information from multiple sources, allowing us to extract patterns and relationships between them.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Interpretations of Matrix Multiplication
contentHtml: In this worked example, we'll explore how to interpret matrix multiplication in terms of linear combinations of columns and dot products.
problemHtml: Consider the matrix product \[A \cdot B = \begin{bmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} e & f \\ g & h \end{bmatrix}\]. What does each entry in the resulting matrix represent?",
description: The resulting matrix represents a linear combination of the columns of B, weighted by the rows of A
explanation: This is the key insight: matrix multiplication represents a linear combination of columns" } ],
finalAnswer: The resulting matrix represents a linear combination of the columns of B, weighted by the rows of A" },
intuition: Matrix multiplication can be thought of as computing the dot product between each row of the first matrix and each column of the second matrix. This allows us to combine and transform the columns of the second matrix in a flexible way.
